title: Analyzing network scale-up data using the networkreporting package
text: networkreporting package several tools analyzing survey data collected using network scale-method. introduction assume already networkreporting package installed. don’t, please refer introductory vignette (“getting started”) instructions .

what: Review of the network scale-up method
title: Analyzing network scale-up data using the networkreporting package
text: purposes vignette, ’ll assume conducted survey using network scale-questions order estimate size hidden population. Analytically, using scale-estimator involves two steps: step 1: estimating size survey respondents’ personal networks (degrees) step 2: estimating size hidden population combining estimated network sizes (step 1) number connections hidden population ’ll quickly review steps, ’ll show use package carry estimation .

previous_headings: Review of the network scale-up method
title: Analyzing network scale-up data using the networkreporting package
text: , use known population estimator respondents’ degrees (Killworth et al., 1998; Feehan Salganik, 2016). order estimate degree ii th survey respondent, use dî=∑j=1Kyij×N∑j=1KNj, \begin{align} \label{eqn:kpdegree} \hat{d_i} = \sum_{j=1}^{K} y_{ij} \times  \frac{N}{\sum_{j=1}^{K} N_j}, \end{align} NN total size population, NjN_j size jj th population known size, yijy_{ij} number connections survey respondent ii reports members jj th population known size.

previous_headings: Review of the network scale-up method
title: Analyzing network scale-up data using the networkreporting package
text: estimates respondents’ degrees, use produce estimate size hidden population: N̂h=∑∈syih∑∈sdî, \begin{align} \label{eqn:nsum} \hat{N}_h = \frac{ \sum_{\s} y_{ih} }{ \sum_{\s} \hat{d_i} }, \end{align} NhN_h size population interest (want estimate), ss set respondents sample, dî\hat{d_i} estimate size respondent ii’s degree, obtained using known population method.

title: Analyzing network scale-up data using the networkreporting package
text: order use package, assume start two datasets: first survey containing information collected respondents personal networks; second information sizes several populations. example data vignette provided networkreporting package, can loaded typing example data include two datasets: one responses network scale-survey, known population sizes use known population estimator.
code: library(networkreporting) library(surveybootstrap)  ## column names for connections to hidden population numbers hidden.q <- c("sex.workers", "msm", "idu", "clients")  ## column names for connections to groups of known size hm.q <- c("widower", "nurse.or.doctor", "male.community.health", "teacher",            "woman.smoke", "priest", "civil.servant", "woman.gave.birth",            "muslim", "incarcerated", "judge", "man.divorced", "treatedfortb",            "nsengimana", "murekatete", "twahirwa", "mukandekezi", "nsabimana",            "mukamana", "ndayambaje", "nyiraneza", "bizimana", "nyirahabimana",            "ndagijimana", "mukandayisenga", "died")  ## size of the entire population tot.pop.size <- 10718378

title: Analyzing network scale-up data using the networkreporting package
text: demo known population data example.knownpop.dat: example.knownpop.dat simple: one column name known population, toal size. expect users typically start small dataset like one. using networkreporting package, useful vector whose entries known population sizes whose names known population names. df..kpvec function makes easy us create : Finally, also need know total size population making estimates . case, let’s assume ’re working country 10 million people:

title: Analyzing network scale-up data using the networkreporting package

title: Analyzing network scale-up data using the networkreporting package
text: Many network scale-studies topcoded responses aggregate relational data questions. means researchers considered responses certain value, called topcode, implausible. proceeding analysis, researchers substitute maximum plausible value implausible ones. example, many studies, researchers replaced responses value 31 higher value 30 conducting analysis (see Zheng, Salganik, Gelman 2006). won’t discuss whether advisable , currently common practice scale-studies. wish follow , can use topcode.data function. example, let’s topcode responses questions populations known size value 30. First, ’ll examine distribution responses topcoding: Several populations, including widower, male.community.health, teacher, woman.smoke, muslim, incarcerated maximum values high. (turns 95 highest value recorded interviews; respondents said connected 95 people group, interviewers wrote 95 .) Now use topcode.data function topcode responses 30: look help page topcode.data, ’ll see can also handle situations variables can take special codes missing values, refusals, forth.

title: Analyzing network scale-up data using the networkreporting package
text: Now finished preparing data, turn esimating sizes respondent’s personal network. using known population estimator, use kp.degree.estimator function: can examine results histogram  Now let’s append degree estimates survey reports dataframe:
code: d.hat <- kp.individual.estimator_(resp.data=example.survey,                                   known.populations=known.popn.vars,                                   total.kp.size=sum(kp.vec),                                   alter.popn.size=tot.pop.size)$dbar.Fcell.F ## NOTE: Ignoring any rows with missingness on any of the report variables. summary(d.hat) ##    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.  ##    0.00   25.28   58.99  101.21  126.42 1904.69 library(ggplot2) # we'll use qplot from ggplot2 for plots theme_set(theme_minimal()) qplot(d.hat, binwidth=25) ## Warning: `qplot()` was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0. ## This warning is displayed once per session. ## Call `lifecycle::last_lifecycle_warnings()` to see where this warning was ## generated. example.survey$d.hat <- d.hat

title: Analyzing network scale-up data using the networkreporting package
text: Now estimated degrees, can use produce estimates size hidden population. , ’ll take example clients female sex workers, clients Note specify use rows dataset missing values missing = "complete.obs" option, also pass total population size using total.popn.size option. resulting estimate returns estimate, also numerator denominator used compute .
code: idu.est <- nsum.estimator(survey.data=example.survey,                           d.hat.vals=d.hat,                           total.popn.size=tot.pop.size,                           y.vals="clients",                           missing="complete.obs") idu.est ## $estimate ## [1] 47798.44 ##  ## $tot.connections ## [1] 1164 ##  ## $sum.d.hat ## [1] 243522.6

title: Analyzing network scale-up data using the networkreporting package
text: order estimate sampling uncertainty estimated totals, can use rescaled bootstrap technique; see Feehan Salganik 2016 rescaled boostrap can applied network scale-method. order use rescaled boostrap, need able specify sampling design study. particular, need able describe stratifcation () primary sampling units used study. default, bootstrap.estimates produces list num.reps entries; entry result calling estimator function one bootstrap resample. Next, can write bit code help us put results together, plotting summarizing can examine summarized results histogram summarize.  produce 95% intervals using percentile method can something like
code: idu.est <- bootstrap.estimates(## this describes the sampling design of the                                ## survey; here, the PSUs are given by the                                ## variable cluster, and the strata are given                                ## by the variable region                                survey.design = ~ cluster + strata(region),                                ## the number of bootstrap resamples to obtain                                ## (NOTE: in practice, you should use more than 100.                                ##  this keeps building the package relatively fast)                                num.reps=100,                                ## this is the name of the function                                ## we want to use to produce an estimate                                ## from each bootstrapped dataset                                estimator.fn="nsum.estimator",                                ## these are the sampling weights                                weights="indweight",                                ## this is the name of the type of bootstrap                                ## we wish to use                                bootstrap.fn="rescaled.bootstrap.sample",                                ## our dataset                                survey.data=example.survey,                                ## other parameters we need to pass                                ## to the nsum.estimator function                                d.hat.vals=d.hat,                                total.popn.size=tot.pop.size,                                y.vals="clients",                                missing="complete.obs") library(plyr) ## combine the estimates together in one data frame ## (bootstrap.estimates gives us a list) all.idu.estimates <- ldply(idu.est,                            function(x) { data.frame(estimate=x$estimate) }) ## look at a histogram of the results qplot(all.idu.estimates$estimate, binwidth=500) ## summarize the results summary(all.idu.estimates$estimate) ##    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.  ##   27067   32759   35606   35465   37922   46234 quantile(all.idu.estimates$estimate, probs=c(0.025, 0.975)) ##     2.5%    97.5%  ## 28318.34 43474.41

title: Analyzing network scale-up data using the networkreporting package
text: want run internal consistency checks (see e.g. Feehan et al., 2016, Fig 3), can use nsum.internal.consistency function. specify wish use complete observations (ie, remove rows missing values calculations). Now ic.result list summary results entry results Since passed argument return.plot=TRUE function, also get plot:  plot ggplot2 object, can customize want. simple example, can change title:  ggplot2 website information modifying ggplot2 objects.
code: ic.result <- nsum.internal.consistency(survey.data=example.survey,                                       known.popns=kp.vec,                                       missing="complete.obs",                                       killworth.se=TRUE,                                       total.popn.size=tot.pop.size,                                       alter.popn.size=tot.pop.size,                                       kp.method=TRUE,                                       return.plot=TRUE) ## NOTE: Ignoring any rows with missingness on any of the report variables. ##  ## NOTE: Ignoring any rows with missingness on any of the report variables. ##  ## NOTE: Ignoring any rows with missingness on any of the report variables. ## title: Average personal network size estimates using known population method — kp.estimator_

'ignore' adds respondent's nonmissing reported connections known populations, effectively treating missing reports 0s. 'complete.obs' uses responses respondents non-missing values known population reports.

title: network survival estimator — network.survival.estimator_
text: Currently, dataframe returned columns attributes death rates calculated , along : num.obs.deaths - number deaths reported num.obs.degree - number respondents cell used estimating degree y.F.Dcell.hat - estimated total number connections frame deaths y.Fcell.kp.hat - estimated total number connections (frame intersect cell) groups known size total.kp.size - total size groups known size N.Fcell.hat - estimated size (frame intersect cell) population (based survey weights) N.F.hat - estimated size frame population (based survey weights) asdr.hat - estimated death rate

title: network survival estimator — network.survival.estimator_
text: want estimated sampling variances, can pass data frame boot.weights. boot.weights assumed column named whatever ego.id , series columns named boot_weight_1, ..., boot_weight_M. ego.id can either string vector strings, can named vector like c(''='b'). second case, '' name id column resp.data, 'b' name id column 'attribute.data'. within.alter.weight weight alters within respondent. set NULL default, many applications need . However, can helpful respondents asked report subset alters. example, suppose respondents can report 10 alters detail. Respondent reports connections 3 deaths, respondent B reports connections 12 deaths. aggregating Respondent 's detailed reports, need use sampling weight. However, used sampling weight aggregating Respondent B's reports, imply Respondent B reported connections 10 deaths. case, setting within.alter.weight (12/10) Respondent B make B's reports imply reported 12 deaths. Note makes assumption 10 deaths Respondent B report uniformly random subsample 12 deaths reports connected .

"complete.obs" use rows missingness computations (listwise deletion). care must taken using second option verbose TRUE, print messages screen ... extra parameters pass bootstrap fn, applicable
